G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as this is a civil action for damages exceeding $50,000 arising within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Bristol County Superior Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the Defendant conducts business and the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Bristol County.

Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.raw_text: Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401 Mass. 788 (1988)
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to supervise children entrusted to its care and to protect them from unreasonable risks of physical harm.
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.case_name: Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.support_reasoning: The case clearly recognizes that Peter Pan and the terminal operator owed a duty of care to a passenger waiting in the terminal, but it does so in the context of common-carrier and premises-liability duties to passengers in a bus terminal, not a distinct, general duty to supervise "children entrusted to its care." The opinion treats the victim as a passenger, not as a child under a special custodial or supervisory relationship, and the duty discussed is the carrier’s heightened duty to protect passengers from assaults in light of foreseeable criminal activity. Thus, it does not specifically establish a Massachusetts rule about a duty to supervise children entrusted to a defendant’s care.
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.relevant_excerpt: "Our cases have long extended passenger status, and thus have imposed a duty of care on a common carrier, to people on its premises for the purposes of transportation... In cases involving injuries caused by assaults or by the violence of other passengers, however, our cases have held the carrier to a high degree of care. See Quigley v. Wilson Line of Mass., Inc., 338 Mass. 125, 128 (1958) ('common carrier owes to its passengers the highest degree of care in the anticipation and prevention of violence...')."

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 41 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: That duty arises from Defendant’s voluntary undertaking to provide organized, supervised childcare services.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that a duty arises from the defendant’s voluntary undertaking to provide organized, supervised childcare services. Leavitt concerns whether a hospital owed a duty to a nonpatient third-party police officer based on theories including voluntary assumption of a duty to protect third parties from impaired patients, and the court expressly rejects the voluntary-assumption theory. The case does not involve childcare services and is cited for the opposite point: that no such voluntarily assumed duty to third parties exists on these facts.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Leavitt contends that a duty of care exists under any one of three theories: general negligence; a ‘special relationship’…; and a voluntary assumption of a duty of care by the hospital to protect third parties from harm caused by ‘impaired’ patients. We reject each theory.”

Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.raw_text: Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262 (1986)
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.proposition: Defendant breached its duty by failing to maintain adequate supervision and by permitting dangerous horseplay among children in its care.
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.support_reasoning: The case concerns an automobile-pedestrian accident and issues of comparative negligence, jury instructions, and loss of consortium/parental society. It does not involve a defendant charged with supervising children, nor does it discuss any duty to supervise or prevent horseplay among children. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for a proposition about negligent supervision of children or permitting dangerous horseplay.
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.relevant_excerpt: Evidence that a pedestrian, knowing that a car was approaching, crossed a road at night without at least glancing in the direction of the car as she proceeded across, raises an issue of negligence for a jury. See, e.g., Legg v. Bloom, 282 Mass. 303, 304-305 (1933); Campbell v. Cairns, 302 Mass. 584, 586 (1939); Herbert v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Authy., 1 Mass. App. Ct. 670, 671 (1974).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions constituted negligence as defined in G.L. c. 231, § 85, which provides that a plaintiff may recover damages where the defendant’s lack of ordinary care causes injury.

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of J.J.’s injuries and of Plaintiff’s resulting economic losses.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses proximate cause where a defendant’s negligence (failure to secure a dangerous instrumentality) leads to injury through a third party’s intervening conduct. The SJC holds that the jury could find the Authority’s negligent failure to secure the forklift was a culpable, direct, and foreseeable cause of the plaintiff’s injuries, notwithstanding the intoxicated seaman’s intervening operation. That holding supports the proposition that a defendant’s negligence can be the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries and resulting economic losses.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury.’ … It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition … would be operated by unauthorized persons… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant failed to meet the standard of care required under Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013), which holds that those supervising children must act reasonably to prevent foreseeable harm.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case deals with a landowner’s premises liability duty to remedy an open and obvious danger, not with a general standard of care for supervising children. The holding is that a landowner who creates and maintains an open and obvious hazardous condition, knowing lawful entrants will encounter it despite the risk, has a duty to remedy that danger. It does not articulate or apply a specific rule about supervisors of children or child supervision standards, so citing it for that distinct proposition is inaccurate.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg… Section 343A thus instructs that although a duty to warn of an open and obvious danger would be superfluous… a landowner is not relieved from remedying that danger where he knows or has reason to know that lawful entrants may not heed the warning….”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: The breach of duty was further contrary to the principles set forth in Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983), recognizing that custodial institutions owe a duty to protect those under their supervision from foreseeable harm.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted text is from a dissent focused on causation, not duty. However, Mullins v. Pine Manor College as a case is well known for recognizing that colleges and similar custodial institutions owe a duty to protect students from foreseeable criminal acts, and the majority opinion (not reproduced here) expressly discusses that duty. Thus, while this excerpt itself does not state the duty rule, the case overall supports the proposition about custodial institutions owing a duty of protection from foreseeable harm.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: [No clear duty-language appears in the provided dissent excerpt; the recognition of the college’s duty to protect students from foreseeable criminal acts is articulated in the majority opinion, which is not included in the quoted text.]

Hobson v. Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (A.raw_text: Hobson v. Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (Aquinnah), 480 Mass. 1009 (2018)
Hobson v. Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (A.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated the standards identified in Hobson v. Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (Aquinnah), 480 Mass. 1009 (2018) (duty arises where relationship creates reliance on defendant for safety).
Hobson v. Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (A.support_reasoning: The provided text from Hobson v. Wampanoag Tribe concerns mootness and the court’s decision not to reach a constitutional identification issue; it does not address tort duties, special relationships, or reliance for safety. There is no discussion of a duty arising from a relationship that creates reliance on the defendant for protection. Thus, the case does not support the stated proposition about a safety-based duty of care.
Hobson v. Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (A.relevant_excerpt: "We decline the juvenile's invitation to decide the appeal notwithstanding its mootness. A challenge to this type of identification procedure may be capable of repetition, as the juvenile claims, but it will not necessarily evade appellate review. Although we recognize that the issue is significant and has constitutional implications, the most prudent course is to defer deciding the issue until we are presented with a case where there is a live controversy."

Campbell v. City of Lynn, 430 Mass. 611.raw_text: Campbell v. City of Lynn, 430 Mass. 611 (2000)
Campbell v. City of Lynn, 430 Mass. 611.proposition: Plaintiff has sustained damages in the form of medical expenses, loss of income, and emotional distress.
Campbell v. City of Lynn, 430 Mass. 611.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a public employer commits a prohibited labor practice by proposing to suspend an employee for nonpayment of an agency fee when the union used improper collection procedures. It does not discuss or find that the plaintiff sustained damages such as medical expenses, loss of income, or emotional distress. There is no mention of such damages or any assessment of them in the court’s reasoning or disposition.
Campbell v. City of Lynn, 430 Mass. 611.relevant_excerpt: An employee who has received an unlawful service fee demand immediately may seek recourse against the union by filing a prohibited labor practice charge. 456 Code Mass. Regs. § 17.06. If an employee took this defensive step, a constitutional claim against the employer would not even arise because the employer may not take any punitive action against the employee for failure to pay the service fee while the charge is pending. 456 Code Mass. Regs. § 17.16(2).

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Plaintiff also relies upon relevant authorities including Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988); Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 Mass. 320 (1974); and Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002), each affirming the principle that negligence liability arises where the defendant’s failure to exercise reasonable care causes injury to a foreseeable victim.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses negligence in terms of a duty to exercise reasonable care in light of foreseeable risks and makes clear that liability arises only when a defendant’s failure to meet that standard causes injury that an ordinarily prudent person would have anticipated. Although the court ultimately finds no negligence on these specific facts because the risk was not sufficiently foreseeable, it expressly affirms the general principle that landowners must maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition considering the likelihood of injury. Thus, it supports the broad proposition about negligence liability tied to failure to exercise reasonable care toward foreseeable victims.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Negligence, without qualification and in its ordinary sense, is the failure of a responsible person, either by omission or by action, to exercise that degree of care, vigilance and forethought which, in the discharge of the duty then resting on him, the person of ordinary caution and prudence ought to exercise under the particular circumstances. … Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’”

Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.raw_text: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 Mass. 320 (1974)
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.proposition: Plaintiff also relies upon relevant authorities including Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988); Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 Mass. 320 (1974); and Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002), each affirming the principle that negligence liability arises where the defendant’s failure to exercise reasonable care causes injury to a foreseeable victim.
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.case_name: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly analyzes the negligence standard owed by the landowner to the plaintiff and upholds liability based on failure to exercise reasonable care toward a foreseeable victim on the premises. The court states the club owed the same duty as to its own employees, defined in terms of reasonable care to discover and warn of hidden defects that cause injury. The jury’s negligence verdict is affirmed on that basis, so the case is properly cited for the general principle that negligence liability arises where a defendant’s failure to exercise reasonable care causes injury to a person foreseeably within the scope of that duty.
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was the employee of an independent contractor working on the club’s premises. The club thereby owed him the same duty it owed its own employees — to disclose hidden or concealed defects on the premises of which it was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care… To recover, the plaintiff had to prove that his injury was caused by the club’s failure to warn him of the hidden defect in the anchor bolt and that this defect was one of which it should have been aware.”

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: Plaintiff also relies upon relevant authorities including Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988); Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 Mass. 320 (1974); and Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002), each affirming the principle that negligence liability arises where the defendant’s failure to exercise reasonable care causes injury to a foreseeable victim.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Coughlin affirms that negligence liability arises where a defendant’s failure to exercise reasonable care causes injury to a foreseeable victim. In this case, however, the Appeals Court held the opposite: as a matter of law Titus & Bean owed no duty because the harm to the victim was not reasonably foreseeable. The opinion discusses foreseeability and duty, but it does so to reject negligence liability, not to affirm that liability existed on these facts, so it does not support the proposition as cited.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, to prove a cause of action founded upon negligence, the plaintiff must satisfy the elements of duty, breach, causation, and damages… Here, the motion judge ruled as matter of law that the defendant did not owe any such duty to the victim.… In sum, a background check would not have provided any additional information that would have enabled Titus & Bean to reasonably foresee that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public at or near 385R Court Street.… As matter of law, Titus & Bean owed the victim no legal duty.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: C. Award interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
